bestBHT.bht: Peter, understanding that Jesus' death would be the time of his own following, is not staggered or hesitant to follow Him to the point of death. He displays an impatience to immediately lay down his life for Jesus, not fully grasping the idea of His death but showing the loyalty of a good disciple. Peter's self-confidence is hurt by Jesus' words, revealing his lack of self-knowledge that needs correction. He recognizes his own weakness as the hindrance to follow Christ immediately, ready to hazard his life in defense of Him.

Henry Alford: 37.] Peter understands our Lord’s death to be meant as the time of his following;—see Luke, ver. 33.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: He seems now to see that it was death Christ referred to as what would sever Him from them."
Is not staggered at following Him thither."
Marvin Vincent: Now [αρτι] . Without waiting for a future time. See on ver. 33, and compare nun now, in ver. 36.
I will lay down my life. See on 10 11.
John Calvin: He is aware that he has been warned of his own weakness, from which he concludes that it is his own fault that hinders him from following Christ immediately."
Mankind are naturally puffed up with confidence in their own value.
The consequence is, that they who can do nothing venture to attempt everything, without imploring the assistance of God.
Philip Schaff: Peter sees that in the words, 'Thou canst not follow me now,' there lies the meaning that he is not yet morally prepared for following Jesus.
His self-confidence is hurt by the suggestion; and not in devotion only, but in too high an estimate of his own readiness to meet every trial for the sake of the Master whom he loved.
Such want of self-knowledge must be corrected.
Archibald T. Robertson: The use of αρτ (right now, this minute) instead of νυν (at this time, verse John 13:36) illustrates the impatience of Peter.
Peter, like the rest, had not yet grasped the idea of the death of Christ, but, like Thomas (John 11:16), he is not afraid of danger.
He had heard Christ's words about the good shepherd (John 10:11) and knew that such loyalty was the mark of a good disciple.
John Gill: Lord, why cannot I follow thee now? is the place inaccessible? are the difficulties in the way to it insuperable?"
I am ready to go through the greatest dangers and difficulties, to follow thee.
I would readily hazard my life, and cheerfully lay it down in defense of thee.

bhtAttempts.bht: Peter, understanding that Jesus' death would be the time of his own following, is not staggered or hesitant to follow Him to the point of death. He demonstrates an impatience to immediately lay down his life for Jesus, not fully grasping the idea of Jesus' death but displaying the loyalty of a good disciple. Peter's self-confidence is hurt by Jesus' words, revealing his lack of self-knowledge that needs correction. He recognizes his own weakness as the hindrance in following Christ immediately, realizing that mankind's natural confidence can lead to attempting everything without relying on God's assistance. With a readiness to go through dangers and difficulties for Jesus, Peter is willing to hazard his life and lay it down in defense of Him.

Peter, noting that Jesus' death would be the time of his own following, is not staggered or hesitant to follow Him to the point of death. He displays an impatience to immediately lay down his life for Jesus, not fully grasping the idea of His death but showing the loyalty of a good disciple. Peter's self-confidence is hurt by Jesus' words, revealing his lack of self-knowledge that needs correction. He recognizes his own weakness as the hindrance to follow Christ immediately, ready to hazard his life in defense of Him.

Understanding that Jesus' death would be the time of his own following, Peter is undeterred and unhesitant to follow Him even to the point of death. His impatience is evident, as he is ready to lay down his life for Jesus right now, not fully comprehending the magnitude of Jesus' impending death. Peter's confidence is shaken by Jesus' response, revealing his need for self-awareness and correction. Despite his lack of understanding, Peter's loyalty and willingness to risk his life for Jesus is commendable.

Peter's self-confidence is hurt by Jesus' words, revealing his lack of self-knowledge that needs correction. He recognizes his own weakness as the hindrance to follow Christ immediately, ready to hazard his life in defense of Him.
